system: OPTKAS1 Funding System — Cryptographic Document Registry
purpose: Immutable cryptographic proof of fully executed agreements for lender leverage and verification

documents.title: Strategic Infrastructure & Execution Agreement
documents.description: Master agreement between OPTKAS1 LLC and OPTKAS1-MAIN SPV governing infrastructure partnership, economic terms, and governance framework

documents.title: Exhibit A — Economic Participation Terms
documents.description: Economic participation schedule defining Option A (10% equity participation) and Option B (4% + 2% success fee) terms for infrastructure sponsor

documents.title: Signature Page — All Parties
documents.description: Consolidated signature page with wet/digital signatures from all authorized signatories of both parties

documents.title: Sponsor Consideration Note
documents.description: Promissory consideration note documenting the economic consideration exchanged between sponsor and SPV as part of the infrastructure arrangement

documents.title: Sponsor Note Estoppel Certificate
documents.description: Estoppel certificate confirming no defaults, outstanding claims, or modifications to the Sponsor Consideration Note — required for lender reliance

documents.title: Consolidated Signature Package — OPTKAS1 LLC Execution Package
documents.description: Master consolidated signature document containing all authorized signatures from both OPTKAS1 LLC and OPTKAS1-MAIN SPV across all agreement documents

verification_instructions.step_1: Download document from IPFS gateway URL
verification_instructions.step_2: Compute SHA-256 hash of downloaded file
verification_instructions.step_3: Compare hash against the sha256 field in this manifest
verification_instructions.step_4: Verify IPFS CID by running: ipfs add -n --only-hash <file>
verification_instructions.step_5: Confirm manifest CID matches the hash manifest pinned at QmedJSTVKKMeCoi4UYt8xTZw9Hhs91ZD4bEdAotB65v1Zm

chain_of_custody.immutability_guarantee: All documents pinned to IPFS with content-addressed hashing. Any modification produces a different CID, making tampering cryptographically detectable.
